title: Brooklyn Housing Price Classification
text:
This project uses logistic regression to classify Brooklyn home sales into price categories using publicly available property data. Key features include square footage, lot size, building class, and year built. The modeling pipeline involves variable selection, VIF-based filtering, and interpretation of odds ratios to understand the impact of structural characteristics on sale price categories.

Tools: R (glm, car, MASS)
Skills: Logistic regression, multicollinearity control, real estate modeling, interpretable ML
Code: ğŸ”— View on GitHub

title: Forecasting CPI with ARIMAX and VAR Models
text:
This project compares two multivariate time series approachesâ€”ARIMAX and simple VARâ€”for forecasting the Consumer Price Index (CPI) using explanatory variables like interest rates and regional price indices. The analysis includes seasonality adjustments, model validation using RMSE, and diagnostic checks such as AIC/BIC selection and residual autocorrelation testing.

Tools: R (forecast, vars, tseries)
Skills: ARIMAX modeling, VAR lag selection, seasonality decomposition, forecast evaluation
Deliverable: ğŸ“„ View Slide Deck (PDF)

title: Champion VAR Modeling for CPI Forecasting
text:
This project focuses on building and refining Vector Autoregressive (VAR) models for forecasting the U.S. Consumer Price Index (CPI) using related economic indicators. It includes a comparison of VAR specifications, evaluation of forecast accuracy, model diagnostics, and presentation of a final â€œchampion modelâ€ selected based on information criteria and residual analysis.

Tools: R (vars, tseries, forecast), Quarto, ggplot2
Skills: VAR lag selection, impulse response analysis, model stability checks, residual diagnostics
Deliverables:

ğŸ“„ Full VAR Modeling Report (PDF)
ğŸ† Champion Model Summary (PDF)

title: Supervised vs.Â Unsupervised Learning on Customer Data
text:
This project compares supervised and unsupervised machine learning approaches using a customer churn dataset. The unsupervised portion uses k-means and Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM) for behavioral clustering, while the supervised side builds tree-based models to predict churn probability. The analysis also includes PCA-based dimensionality reduction and visualization techniques to evaluate separability between churn groups.

Tools: R, cluster, mclust, caret, rpart, ggplot2
Skills: K-means, GMM, PCA, decision trees, cluster validation, churn modeling
Notebook: ğŸ““ View on GitHub

title: Clustering the Ames Housing Market
text:
This project uses unsupervised learning techniques to identify clusters of homes in the Ames Housing dataset. K-means and Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM) are applied to engineered numeric features to uncover latent structure in buyer behavior and home characteristics. PCA is used to reduce dimensionality for visualization and assess the distinctiveness of clusters. Insights are drawn about housing submarkets and remodeling patterns.

Tools: Python (scikit-learn, pandas, seaborn, matplotlib)
Skills: K-means, GMM, PCA, cluster interpretation, unsupervised modeling
Notebook: ğŸ““ View on GitHub

title: Exploring Latent Structure with PCA and LCA
text:
This project applies Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Latent Class Analysis (LCA) to uncover hidden structure within behavioral or transactional data. PCA is used to reduce dimensionality while retaining interpretability through loadings, and LCA identifies distinct subgroups based on latent variable modeling. The goal is to compare these techniques in identifying meaningful clusters or behavioral profiles that are not directly observable.

Tools: Python (sklearn, numpy, matplotlib), R (poLCA)
Skills: PCA, LCA, component loading analysis, latent class modeling, dimension reduction
Notebook: ğŸ““ View on GitHub
